docs.lead_paragraph: HEALTH CARE ON THE ROAD www.highwaytohealth.com Imagine that you are visiting a foreign country when a pain in the back doesn't respond to aspirin, or your child shows signs of an ear infection, or your spouse develops a fever. You don't speak the language and you don't know the name of a doctor (or medecin or medico). HighwaytoHealth, a Web service based in Radnor, Pa., is designed to help you find, get and pay for medical care while traveling. For an annual membership fee of $19, a traveler is covered around the world for any number of trips. The service says more than 18,000 physicians in 80 some countries -- I didn't count them -- belong to the network.
docs.abstract: Cyberscout column on HighwaytoHealth, Web service designed to help travelers, for a fee, get and pay for medical care while traveling; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Congress that began with the traumatic Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton ended its first session on Friday night with both political parties fine-tuning campaign slogans for next year's high-stakes election and blaming each other for having lost the art of legislating. The compromise that allowed the Senate to pass the year's last spending package and adjourn for the year came seven weeks after the start of the new fiscal year. The deal came on legislation that must pass to keep the government running. But beyond the spending bills, the 106th Congress has mostly been characterized by fierce politicking, missed opportunities and legislative standoff.

headline.main: Underlying Tensions Kept Congress Divided to the End

docs.abstract: Compromise that allows Senate to pass year's last spending package and adjourn for year comes seven weeks after start of new fiscal year; beyond spending bills, that must be passed to keep government running, 106th Congress hasmostly been characterized by fierce politicking, missed opportunities and legislative standoff; chart with highlights of budget accord (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On second thought, maybe all the seesawing in the candidate polls means little or nothing. At least that is essentially the view of the 1,007 voters contacted last weekend by Harvard's Vanishing Voter Project. More than half of them told the project's poll takers that they were paying little to no attention to the presidential race, mostly because they were too busy or because it was too early in the campaign or because they were just apathetic or plain alienated.

headline.main: The Persistent Yawns Of Presidential Voters

docs.lead_paragraph: HIS name may not be familiar to anyone but his own employees, but chances are you've heard about what Al Galdi has done: given new BMW's to any employee who has worked at his company for at least a year. During the last six months, Mr. Galdi has handed out BMW keys to 34 of his 45 employees. The cars, which are leased, cost him about $9,000 a year each, including insurance. Needless to say, turnover at Arcnet, an architectural engineering firm in Holmdel, N.J., has been virtually nil since Mr. Galdi began offering the perk in June. Employees who leave have to give back the cars.

headline.main: Better Perks Resonate in Boom Times

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY summer, Steven E. Folker treks up to his cabin in the northern Wisconsin woods near Chequamegon Bay to cast his line for smallmouth bass and lake trout. The rest of the year, he seeks bigger fish -- large-capitalization, high-quality growth companies that will end up in the portfolio of the fund he manages, Fifth Third Quality Growth. ''We want companies that historically have been able to consistently grow their earnings at above-average rates,'' Mr. Folker said from his office at the headquarters of Fifth Third Bancorp in Cincinnati, overlooking the coal and oil barges that dot the Ohio River. ''More important, we want companies with strong earnings growth in the next three to five years.''

headline.main: INVESTING WITH: Steven E. Folker; Fifth Third Quality Growth Fund

docs.lead_paragraph: The state's unemployment rate dropped for the fourth straight month, a decline that some say is likely to continue and result in the state's lowest jobless rate in history. ''What we are seeing here is the largest peacetime expansion of jobs since we've been keeping records,'' said Carl Van Horn, director of the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University.

headline.main: Heading for a Record Low, Unemployment Rate Drops

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was lots of news on the campaign trail last week, from Governor George W. Bush's foreign policy debut to new polls in New Hampshire showing a tightening horse race in both parties. But is anyone paying attention, beyond the rapt little world of journalists, consultants and political groupies? A new survey suggests that most Americans are not. When people weren't prompted with a list of candidates, which is routinely done in political polls, nearly two-thirds said they did not have a favorite. More than 8 in 10 did not know whether former Senator Bill Bradley advocated government-paid health insurance for low-income people. (He does.) Nearly 8 in 10 had no idea whether Senator John McCain supported or opposed an overhaul of the campaign finance system. (He supports it.)

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; If a Poll Falls in the Forest and No One Hears It ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Most Americans may not know it, but there are really two Wall Streets. One is the Wall Street of the New York Stock Exchange closing bell, of brash stockbrokers and hair-trigger traders, of big deals and big fortunes, of Microsoft and mutual funds.

headline.main: DANGEROUS DEALS: A special report.; Penny Stock Fraud Is Billion-Dollar Game

docs.abstract: Special report, Dangerous Deals, on penny stock fraud; in crooked alleys of Lower Manhattan flourishes another Wall Street, a world of low-priced stocks and high-priced dreams, of grimy offices and sham companies, of swindlers and touts who prey on average people trying to grab brass ring in greatest bull market in American history; like world of organized crime, with which it increasingly overlaps, it is a violent place full of colorful characters and arcane lingo; it was in this world that Albert Alain Chalem and Maier Lehmann lived, and died; men, who were promoting stocks over the Internet together, were both shot in head on Oct 25 and left to die in $1.1 million home in Colts Neck, NJ, where Chalem lived; securities regulators say denizens of penny stock underworld bilk Americans out of roughly $2 billion a year; drawings illustrate sequence of how a penny stock fraud is perpetrated (L)
